title: Is social media a distraction?
intro: How often do you check your phone? According to some stats, it's a minimum of 85 times a day. Neil and Sophie discuss how social media is interrupting our lives and may be changing our physiology too!
this_week_question: Which word describes a situation where you're talking to someone and they suddenly look down at their phone or answer it? Is it…
You can hear the right answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: rules of polite behaviour in society or among people in a certain group
say or do something deliberately in order to annoy someone
the way a living thing works or functions

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Sophie…

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Neil? … [sound of a smartphone] Neil!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh, sorry! … And I'm Neil.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Neil, please put down your phone. We're doing the show!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yeah, I know. Hang on a minute. I just need to tweet something and… Done!

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: And the subject of today's show is social media and its impact on our daily lives.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hmm, well, I suppose it has had quite a big impact on mine.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: That's all too clear. Now, perhaps we can move on to today's quiz question?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Of course – I'm all ears. [sound of a smartphone] Oh, hang on, wait a second…

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: There's a word to describe what you're doing, you know. Answer me this: Which word describes a situation where you're talking to someone and they suddenly look down at their phone or answer it? Is it…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, you've got me there, Sophie! I have no idea! But I'll guess that it's c) phubbing!

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Well, we'll find out later on in the show whether you got the answer right or not. Now, let's move on and talk about phone etiquette – etiquette means rules of polite behaviour in society or among people in a certain group.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well… interrupting conversations to check your phone has become a social norm, hasn't it, Sophie?

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Social norms are the rules of behaviour considered acceptable in a group or society. I don't agree, Neil! Let's listen to Professor Sherry Turkle of Massachusetts Institute of Technology talking about social norms amongst students.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Sherry Turkle, American clinical psychologist and professor of the social studies of Science and Technology at Massachusetts Institute of Technology I interviewed hundreds of college students and what they talked about was what some of them called 'the rule of three'. And what the rule of three is which is that if you go to dinner with friends, you don't want to look down at your phone until you see that three people, let's say you're six at dinner, are looking up in the conversation. So there's a new etiquette where you don't look down unless three people are looking up kind of to keep a little conversation alive.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Professor Sherry Turkle.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Why don't you try out the rule of three once in a while?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: There are only two of us here, Sophie - do the math! And I'm listening to you… mmm… let me just send a text message here on my phone ... hang on…

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Neil… NEIL! I'm not going to carry on with the show unless you pay attention!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Sorry, Sophie. Actually I was just doing that to wind you up. I wasn't really using my phone… Sorry.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: And to wind someone up means to say or do something deliberately in order to annoy someone. Well, I do get wound up about people constantly checking their devices. Yesterday, I was in a café and two girls came in. They sat down and started chatting away – but not to each other – they were tapping away at their devices. And there was no face-to-face conversation at all!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But you can have moments of connection using your devices, you know?

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: If you have a connection with someone you engage emotionally.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Exactly. I was on the train this morning and there were a couple sharing a tablet. They were looking at the screen, and talking about what they saw there. It was very intimate, and they were… well… very connected. Let's hear from Ian Sinclair, British poet and filmmaker, talking about a new generation of connected humans.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Iain Sinclair, British writer, poet, and filmmaker Physiologically we're changing, that almost the neck muscles are tipped over to look down. We're getting a new kind of human being. And I think – maybe I'm not getting it – but there is actually a different kind of intimacy emerging in which these instruments are very important.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: So Iain Sinclair says our physiology is changing – our bodies, our neck muscles are changing – to make it easier to look down all the time at our devices! But it isn't only muscles that might change as a result of our techie habits – it's the way we interact – or engage with each other too. Ian Sinclair talks about a different kind of intimacy emerging – what does he mean, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Our intimacy – or closeness – with other people is somehow connected up with our devices. They've become part of us. And I expect some day devices will literally be part of us – an implant in our necks or something.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: What a horrible thought!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Let's have the quiz question again Sophie to take your mind off it.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: OK. I asked: Which word describes a situation where you're talking to someone and they suddenly look down at their phone or answer it? Is it…a) phobbing? b) phibbing? Or c) phubbing?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said c) phubbing.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: You were right, Neil! Well done! It's a combination of' 'phone' and 'snubbing' – snub means to deliberately ignore someone you know. New words formed by putting together parts of existing words are known as blends or portmanteau words. And 'phubbing' is starting to appear in some online dictionaries. Now can we hear the words we learned today?

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Neil? OK! I'll say the words myself: etiquette wind someone up have a connection with someone physiology interact intimacy snub

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Don't forget to connect with us again soon! Come on Neil, connect with us! Come on!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh, yeah, hang on, just got to…

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Goodbye!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hang on… I'll be with you in a second… Yes. OK. Bye!
